title: Which current candidate for the U.S. House of Representatives will the Center for Responsive Politics list as having raised the most money this election cycle?
preds: Data tabulated to resolve this question is open until 12/1/18. Trone currently has a significant but not insurmountable lead.

OpenSecrets Top 3:
Trone, David (D)
(Maryland District 06)	$16,524,302
Wallace, Scott (D)
(Pennsylvania District 01)	$13,925,299
Nunes, Devin (R)*
(California District 22)	$11,643,750
Trone has a huge lead for the house but I think there is still a chance that one of the three behind him could raise a lot suddenly.

Per 538's analysis, wealthy candidates Wallace and Cisneros apparently are in tight election races; Trone and Nunes may not be...: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/house/ http://www.witf.org/news/2018/10/1st-district-race-more-expensive-than-us-senate-contest.php

Nunes and Wallace funding totals move up a little higher as of 10/28/18: https://www.opensecrets.org/overview/topraise.php?cycle=2018&display=S&view=topraise&type=C2 Among the current "leaders", Wallace and Cisneros  - along with Trone - would seem to have the means to make quick, large self-donations to their campaigns.  As previously noted Wallace and Cisneros appear to be in close races.  https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/house/pennsylvania/1/ https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/house/california/39/
Mr. Money man Trone! His "consultants" must be in money heaven looking to cash the famouos 10% commision of all those ads and 20% management fee!

Based on numbers from opensecrets.org, Trone (1st) has nearly a $2.6 million lead over Wallace (2nd).  538.com projects a 99% chance of Trone winning so doubtful to see much of a spike in fundraising leading up to final days of the election.   Only close raises in terms of outcome are Cisneros (57.9% to win) and Wallace (56% to win) so there may be bumps in terms of dollars raised in the short term.   Given the average daily contribution of ~ $2300 and the short amount of days left until the election, looks like Trone has it locked in.

Not observing significant changes at the top of the funding 'scoreboard' thus far, as election day draws closer.
https://www.opensecrets.org/overview/topraise.php?cycle=2018&display=S&view=topraise&type=C2 FWIW: Wallace says he won't take money from "corporate PACs or lobbyists". Campaign appears to be largely self-funded.  http://www.theintell.com/news/20181017/rep-brian-fitzpatrick-scott-wallace-on-track-to-break-spending-records https://bethesdamagazine.com/bethesda-beat/politics/trone-pumps-another-4-5-million-in-personal-funds-into-his-congressional-bid-latest-filings-show/

6 million is a massive gap, and consensus also thinks so. Trone, David (D)    (Maryland District 06)	$16,510,092
Nunes, Devin (R)* (California District 22)	$10,524,567

The top 4 are  Trone, David (D)
(Maryland District 06)	$16,510,092
Nunes, Devin (R)*
(California District 22)	$10,524,567
Cisneros, Gil (D)
(California District 39)	$9,954,354
Wallace, Scott (D)
(Pennsylvania District 01)	$9,810,876 David Trone is the clear winner, but the order may change.

Not currently forecasting it, but large, late contributions to -- or from -- one of the top candidates could still conceivably change the $$'s "scoreboard".  Cisneros and Wallace may be in close races. https://www.opensecrets.org/overview/topraise.php?cycle=2018&display=S&view=topraise&type=C2 https://patch.com/california/orange-county/megamillions-lottery-winner-campaigning-hard-39th-district http://www2.philly.com/philly/columnists/clout/scott-wallace-richest-in-congress-pennsylvania-first-district-20180504.html

"More info" says
"..."Current Candidates Only" (e.g., Jon Ossoff is not a current candidate) and "Current Cycle Only."
Sticking with my analysis. Damn the unknown unknowns, full steam ahead.

Have *NOT* confirmed these are the top 4. I have confirmed Ossoff is not a 'current candidate' if you are wondering why his name isn't on the list.  https://www.opensecrets.org/overview/topraise.php
Assuming the provided list it right, it is a 1 horse race.  My analysis gives all other candidates <0.5%, giving 11% to #2,3,4 to discount for unknown unknowns on election reporting.
